caption: Nice place to take a break. Playground equipment needs a little maintenance. Cannot see Bastille stones- they are fenced off for construction.

Tiny park surrounded by traffic but a lot of locals seem to come here with their children on weekdays. At one corner, they have the only remnant of one of the towers of the Bastille fortress, moved here from further up the road!

Very small city park at the Sully-Morland Metro exit in the 4th district. Beyond the grass here, there is a pile of remains from the historic fortress of the Bastille that were placed here, beyond the original location of Bastille before it was destroyed in French Revolution.  This makes for an interesting quick stop to view the old form remnants, otherwise, not much to see here.
Went to this park with our lunch. Nice place to sit and eat conveniently
Playground with stone pavement is very dangerous for kids, it's much better to have shock-absorbing layer on the floor to prevent injuries!
Cute small park for children, clean too
A nice park to walk, or to run and exercise.

caption: Cute beautiful and green park
Nice
Average. Nothing special.
Super
Cool

Small tree-lined square with children's play area. Plane trees, Crimean lime trees and yews shade the remains of the foundations of the Liberty Tower, one of the eight towers of the Bastille. This fortress, which was partly located on the current Place de la Bastille, marked the Saint-Antoine gate located at the level of the so-called Charles V enclosure. The Bastille, a state prison, was stormed on the 14th. July 1789 by the revolutionaries, then dismantled from 1790. It was during the construction of the first metro line linking Vincennes to Place de l'Etoile that the remains of this tower were unearthed in 1899, rue Saint-Antoine. They were moved and reassembled here stone by stone. The square is dedicated to the journalist and writer Henri Galli, pseudonym of Henri Gallichet (1854-1922), municipal councilor of the 4th arrondissement from 1900 to 1919 and deputy for the Seine from 1914 to 1922.
It's a pretty square with a section reserved for children. Too bad this place is noisy.
This small triangle park is well laid out with games for children. When I was there, there was a group of primary school students who were having a blast.

We visited this park to look at the remains of a Bastille tower foundation. Too bad it is no longer highlighted. The plaque is not very readable, it is on the Seine side, behind (you have to walk in the grass...). 27/8/19

A nice little square with games for children, benches to rest and enjoy the greenery but also table tennis tables (don't forget your rackets and balls). You are right in front of Île Saint Louis in a top neighborhood.

Place where the ruins of the Bastille are located, but unknown to many who walk there. Its most frequent visitors, the rats, you didn't read that wrong, rats, almost the size of cavies, roam freely, looking for food in the square's rubbish baskets. The square is a little abandoned.
This little square is stuck in the middle of the roads. However, it houses a monument that confuses me. The displaced remains of the Freedom Tower, yes it is indeed the bastille we are talking about.

Lovely little park near the Pont de Sully bridge in Paris since 1925, with a playground, barrier-free, benches, no toilet. Named after the writer and journalist Galli (1854-1922), who was a city councilor of the 4th arrondissement, also president of the city council in 1912 & 1913.

It is really regrettable to see the state of this square and that it is never cleaned. The children's games are dirty and you never see people passing by to kick the karcher. It’s deplorable to see this in the middle of Paris and with so many tourists frequenting it.

Unusual square with fragments of the Bastille, symbol of the French Revolution. Too bad this mini triangular park is at the intersection of 3 very dense and noisy roads. Also the presence of rats, more and more numerous in Parisian gardens. Summary: interesting for the historical fragments and/or a break of 5 to 15 minutes maximum to rest or eat, but beyond that, too noisy and too ratty!
I think it's sad that these remains are not highlighted more... Instead, we have a garden shed and a mess... Too bad...

Small, friendly square for children with two games for two age groups: 2-6 years old and 6-14 years old... good for siblings. Table tennis tables. When it is not frequent by people having inappropriate words and behavior and leaving their bottle of alcohol on the ground! Damage !

A square surrounded by streets with heavy car traffic... At the foot of line 7. Games for children, including one with a very high slide which will thrill both children and parents. Ping-pong tables. No public toilets. There is Wi-Fi!

Very small square framed by the main streets around and which offers a play area for children... Remarkable especially for the remains of the "Bastille" which is on the side and which will interest history lovers... However, not a square that makes you want to linger if only because of the intense surrounding traffic...and the proximity of the banks of the Seine, which are much more pleasant!!
Small park equipped with fun games, perfect for letting off steam with the children. Too bad to be surrounded by traffic noise and exhaust fumes...

A little oasis that brings greenery to the middle of a busy and, therefore, noisy intersection. But also a meeting with history thanks to the Liberty Tower which is exposed and well highlighted there.
Quite nice despite being surrounded by traffic on all sides. Slightly dangerous games for children, very high and not secure enough.

Square surrounded by cars still squatted as a playground by a private school whose children see the other little ones without any problem.. agreement with the town hall? Just unbearable getting worse and worse 3 schools are fighting over this park.. 3 schools but 3 classes at the same time a disaster for the little ones
Very clearly and openly children's garden with play equipment. Pleasant break nevertheless unless budding footballers are there.
I've been going there since I was 7 years old. Great park for playing ping pong or rollerblading/trotti thanks to its cycle path.
We discovered lots of mice there!!!! Let Paris City Hall do something!
The most interesting are the remains of a Bastille tower which was transported here after the digging of the metro. Games for children but too much car traffic around.
Car traffic around the park is quite intense, which unfortunately makes this park quite noisy.
I appreciated the games for children and the tranquility in a square so close to a large, very noisy boulevard.
Pretty little urban park with games for children and part of the foundations of the Bastille visible in a corner of the park.
A very pretty wooded square, very pleasant to come and read, the children babble and play in a very pleasant and relaxing place. A little thumbs up is always nice
